passages.text:
TRANSFER BRYAN HILTY
TOAMACHINE GUN CO.

Well, I hava been a soldier for
nearly three weeks and it sure is one
great life, believe me,
We arrived at camp on the 7th of

August and a bunch of non-coms met
us and lined us all up and marched us
out about two miles and all the  sol-
diers along the way would say, “Hep,
hep.” We finally arrived at the hos-
pital and the doctor looked us over to
‘gee if we had any contagious diseases
and then we were made to take a bath.
It wasn’t Saturday night saI_ took
cold, Ha, Ha. Then we were stripped
for gym and started through the
ropes, There were about 50 doctors,
We had to go through out 30 rooms,
and talk about examination, it sure
was some task. And then the last—
well, you have an idea what is was,
haven’t you? Well,,I have heard of
snake bites and had them bite mp, but
that shot in the arm. I though he ran
the needle up in my neck, Then an-
other scratched me on the other arm,
I think they call it vaccination and oh,
look out, I went over to the personal
office to make out my insurance, and
about an hour—that shot hit me and I
got so sick I was afraid I would die,
Then the next morning n§y arm was
swollen up so I was afraid I would
fie, Gee, it sure was a very unpleas-
ant feeling, but in nine days I was
feeling fine and they lined us up and
shot us again, And the fellow ahead
of me fainted and that did get my
goat, But I got through all O, K. I
was in the G company of the 8th Inf.—
in fact, all six of the Mohave county
boys were in it until last Friday, A
big fellow came up and called “Hilty”
and I thought I was picked to be a
kitchen police—that is, clean pans and
peel spuds, But, no, I was being trans-
ferred to the machine gun company,
Oh, gee, that is where you get eight
minutes to live in the front line
trenches, But, believe me, you don’t
have to pack a big rifle, I did that for
two weeks and I asked the officer
when he gave me my gun where the
wheels were and I very nearly got
court martialed, But he smiled,

One consolation with a machine
gun, you sure can get a bunch of those
square-headed Dutch, They only shoot
600 shots a minute, There are eight
men to one gun and they are good for
64 minutes, Gee, that makes a fellow
feel pretty good, doesn’t it?

I suppose you miss me at the dances
and baseball gantes, But it won’t be
THE MOHAVE COUNTY MINER AND OUR MINERAL WEALTH, SATURDAY, AUGUST 31, 1918,
|BILL HARRIS AND

GEORGE GRANTHAM
BACK FOR A VISIT

Donald (Bill) Harris and George
Grantham arrived in town Thursday
from the naval training station at
San Diego! and will remain for some
days visiting with friends and rela-
tives. Both young men are looking in
the best of health and would justify
all the claims thatt they have for the
good treatment that Uncle Sam is af-
fording them, All of our young lady |

friends can see Bill and George at
the big dance being given tonight by
the Camp Fire Girls,

MEETS HIS DEATH
ON ITALIAN FRONT

Mike Sartini, who was called to his ,
old home in Italy by that country’s ,
entry into the great war, was killed ,

in a Hun bombing raid back of the
lines,
Sartini, worked in the mines,
but the call of his native land and
old home ties was too much for him |

and he had to respond to the appeal of
Italy that he aid of all her ‘sons was
needed to repel the invaders,

GEORGE I. GISBON
ON WAY TO FRANCE

George I, Gibson, Company F; 27th
Engineers, has been transfered to
regimental headquarters and is now
on the way to France, Gibson ex-
pects to receive a commission soon,
He is the son of eGorge W. Gobson
of Kingn}an,

long until we will have those square-
heads backed off the map. Now, please
hurry and write me alll the news and
tell all my friendg that want to know
about me that I am going to take my-
self and a machine gun and bust into
Berlin for Christmas, So come ahead
and let’s all:go over the top. I will
have to close and go to mss, Write
soon, I am as ever one of the bunch,
Sincerely,
ISAAC B, (Briney) HILTY.

P. S.—My address: Prvt, Isaac B.,
Hilty, Mach, Gun Co., 62d Inf,, Camp
Fremont, Calif,

He was quite well known in|
Oatman, where he and a brother, R, |
Sarti- |
ni was a citizen of the United States, |

AJ EROME CARROW:
WOULD HATE TO
JEROME CARROW.

Jerome Carrow has been across the
water for weeks now and. says he
would not have missed it for a great
jdeal, He writes: :
“I am, back at headquarters now.

We finished the work we were on sev-
eral days ago ‘and made a very, nice
job of it, Everyone worked up to the
“rep” we have—and it is very good,
for the batallion has. made good on
all the work they have undertaken,

“The weather is most beautiful here,
One would hardly believe it is sum-
mer,

“T had a trip across the country the
other day and enjoyed it very much,
We saw some old towns and the roads
and surrounding country are beautiful,

“Don’t worry about me over here
for I am enjoying it very much andj
am having an experience I would hate’
to miss, One can never know if they | i
are not mixed in it.

TRANSFERRED TO
ENGINEERS’ CORPS

A letter was received by a Kingman
lady from) Paul Morton who is now in
France, in which he states that he

Cattle Range For Sale

One of the choicest stock ranges in Mohave County
on the Wallapai valley slope of the Cerbat range,
thirty-five miles north of Chloride, wherq the rain-
fall is always bountiful and the grasses the best
that grow in the country.
An abundance of water piped through an inch and
unfailing supply.

saw “Casey” Jones and many other
Mohave county boys there. These
men are in the Miner’s Engineer
corps, to which Mr, Morton was re-
cently transferred, Morton was or-
iganally in the gas and flame brigade
and billeted with the aviation branch
of the service,

from Canfp Cody to the eastern coast.

above city and were going to a plunge | #
for a bath, and when: mounting sonfe | iy
WTA BROKER LEB

Henry Sturzenegger suffered a se- :
vere injury at Kansas: City some time
HAVE MISSED IT ago, while enroute with his company :
concrete steps leading} into the plunge OT

building, the officer gave the order
to double quick,. In responding to the | §
order Henry fell and. struck the con- |
crete which resulted im the bursting | i
of his knee cap,
immediately taken after the injury.

from the army, but Henry and his
friends are pulling for sompthing dif-
ferent and it is hoped that his youth
will conquer and that he will come
|forth from the hospital as good as
new and be able to rejoin his company
in the pursuit of the Boche,
PAUL DICKEY NOW
A LIEUTENANT|§

Paul Dicky, son of Mrs, A, N, Keech |
is now a lieutenant in|
the officers training camp at Camp|§

a resident of Hackberry )'a year ago|@
but enlisted when war.was declared |B

THE KAISER STARTED |
SOMETHING HARD TO :
FINISH, SAYS MOORE |

Harry Williams received. a. letter 5
from James Moore,, thanking him for |}

forwarding his Elks’ membership card,
He said:
“Everything is going/ nicely here |}

|with me, Army life is no hardship on
an old ‘desert rat,’ Get plenty to eat
and always have good quarters to sleep
in,

“You get more news in the papers
at honte than I will be able to give you
so will not attempt any news stunts,
Only this—all the boys at this base are
doing their bit and doing it well, The
Germans started something when they
started this last drive, that they could
not finish, I think the allies will finish
it for them, The American boys’
going strong and for everyone who
pays the price several Huns will do
likewise, Am awfully glad to get my
card, There are lots of Bills over
here and it is embarrassing to claim
membership and not be able to show
credentials,”

WHAT YOUR SUBSCRIPTION

When you. subscribe to the Fourth
Liberty Loan you subscribe to the
sentiment that the world must be
made safe for democracy and sub-
seribe to the fund thet is to make the
world safe for demeeracy,

You subscribe to the belief that in-
nocent women and ehildren on un-
armed ships shall met be sent to the
bottom of the sea; that women and
children and old: men shall not be rav-
ished and tortured and murdered un-
der the plea of military necessity;
that nurses shall net be shot for deeds
of mercy, nor hospital ships be sunk
without warning, or hospitals and
unfortified cities be bombed or can-
nonadedé with long-range guns,

You subscribe to the doctrine that
small nations have the same rights as
great and powerful ones; that might
is not right, and that Germany shall
not force upon the world the dontinion
of her military masters,

You subscribe, when you subscribe
to a Liberty Loan, to the belief that
America entered this war for a just
and noble cause; that our soldiers in
France and our sailors on the’ sea are
fighting for right and justice,

And you subscribe to the American
sentiment that they must and shall be
powerful, efficient, and victorious,
Prepare yourself to subscribe for

the Fourth Liberty. Loan Bonds on
a 29th,

Cement reservoirs and tanks give a storage capa-
city of forty thousand gallons as a reserve in case of
need.

This range has never been stocked. The water has
been used for milling the ores of the Cyclopic mine,
but due to the installation of a dry crushing plant I
have no use for the water.
I ALSO OFFER FOR SALE
The Cyclopic Mine and Mill

This mine has been a constant producer for the
past twenty years, and has a practically inexhaust-
ible supply of ore in sight.

It is now under lease and is paying me a handsome
royalty monthly.

IT IS ONE OF THE THREE PRODUCING GOLD
MINES IN MOHAVE COUNTY.

It is equipped with a new modern 100-ton mill and
cyanide plant.

The ore is hoisted by self-dumping skip from the
mine to the mill-

Over fifteen hundred feet of drifts and crosscuts
with spacious ore pockets under the ore bodies make
the breaking, tramming and hoisting of the ore the
last word in efficiency.

The cost of mining and reducing the ore is but two
dollars and thirty cents per ton.

A complete assay office is connected with the prop-
erty.

An electric light plant furnishes all buildings, in-
cluding living houses, boarding house, assay office,
and mill with electric light. The water is piped to
every house.
And the Price?

I will take $30,000 for the complete property, in-
cluding mines, mill and range, or I will sell separate-
ly, either unit for $16,000.

I forgot to state that the camp is connected with
thd state telephone system by a private wire ten
miles to White Hills.

You can reach me over the wire between 12 and
1 o’clock or evenings after 7 o’clock.

Or. write to me at Chloride, or if you are deeply
interested come out and see me.

THE FINEST CATTLE RANGE, THE GREAT-
EST GOLD MINE, THE BEST CLIMATE AND THE
MOST ATTRACTIVE CAMP IN ARIZONA.
Stanley C. Bagg
